awd_titl_txt: Solutions of Nonlinear Hyperbolic and Mixed Type Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
When an airplane's flight speed is close to the speed of sound (the so-called transonic regime), the airflow around the plane has very unusual properties: in some areas the flow is supersonic, and in other areas the flow is subsonic; these two are separated by a surface where the flow is exactly sonic (i.e., has the speed of sound). The sonic surface is attached to the airfoil, and characteristics of the flow, such as drag and lift, change dramatically along the airfoil when the sonic surface is crossed. This causes a serious strain experienced by the airfoil. Mathematical description of this phenomenon is given by partial differential equations (PDE) of mixed type that are the main subject of this project. Other applications of similar equations are found in fluid and quantum mechanics, general relativity, bio-sciences, and plasma physics. Although these equations are widely used and serve as a foundation of some engineering tasks, for example, of the computer-aided design in aerodynamics, among others, and despite recent extensive studies of mixed type PDE, many fundamental mathematical questions concerning the behavior of their solutions are still unresolved. In this project, the Principal Investigator will study simpler, frequently used systems and classes of initial data that play a paramount role in understanding the wave interaction, asymptotic behavior of solutions and their stability. This project will also serve as a training ground for graduate and undergraduate students who will contribute to this research. 

Several model systems of PDE will be studied whose solutions involve the so-called singular shocks, where at least one state variable develops an extreme concentration in the form of a weighted Dirac delta function. These can be used as building blocks for gaining a broader knowledge, insight and perspective on global in time existence of large solutions to systems of conservation laws in one spatial dimension. Differential equations in several spatial dimensions will also be considered. Simpler cases of solutions with spherical symmetry are among the principal topics of this project. Diverse tools from dynamical systems, geometry, harmonic and Fourier analysis will be used in this project. The ultimate goal of this research is to find building blocks that provide information on models of compressible fluid flow and can be used in a well-defined construction scheme to approximate solutions for any initial data.

por.por_cntn:
Despite recent progress in the analysis of hyperbolic and mixed type partial differential equations (PDEs), we lack a good mathematical understanding of the weak solution concept, entropy admissibility conditions used to single out a unique physical solution, and a natural function space to consider for well-posedness of solutions. Many of these issues are raised in applications and are still unresolved.  

The PI studied systems and classes of initial data, that play a paramount role in developing methods that can provide an understanding of wave interactions, asymptotic behavior, and stability. A long term goal is to incorporate special solutions into approximation schemes and therefore establishing rigorous existence via methods with predictive power beyond abstract existence results is necessary. The need to validate and further analyze special solutions to be used as building blocks was the main motivation for this work. Theoretical conditions for existence of weak entropy solutions were developed, and the existing theory was extended, drawing connections with current works. 

The PI was interested in the multi-dimensional Euler system of compressible gas-dynamics. Little is known about how to analytically construct the global weak entropy solution even in the one-dimensional case with large data. Throughout this work, the PI considered the natural simpler case of solutions with planar, cylindrical, and spherical symmetry. By imposing this symmetry, one obtains a one-dimensional initial-boundary value problem with boundary conditions which must be prescribed at the origin. In addition, the flux depends explicitly on the spatial variable and the source term is singular which reflects a truly multi-dimensional effect whereby waves are amplified as they approach the origin. All this precludes any use of one-dimensional techniques, even for arbitrarily small initial amplitudes. In order to obtain existence results of solutions defined on all of space, one must necessarily contend with unbounded solutions. It is well-known that even initially smooth flows in general suffer gradient blow-up, but we are concerned with the much less studied phenomenon of amplitude blowup. The systems we obtain serve as models for various purposes: in early stages of the gas flow between fragments of a bomb explosion with spherical or cylindrical casing; on cliff blasting with boreholes in the mining industry; piston engine flow; nuclear explosions. 

We are also interested in similarity solutions that solve a related system of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and in the issue of blowup of physical quantities and unique continuation of solutions beyond collapse. Our motivation and main interest was to identify more or less explicit bona fide weak solutions that are singular in some sense, since they would point to what a natural data class would be. By using similarity solutions one can assemble solutions where a single, converging shock or an incoming continuous wave collapses on the origin, and then reflects off a diverging shock wave. 

Two types of similarity flows were initially considered for the multi-dimensional Euler system for compressible flow. In the first one, a single incoming shock wave propagates into a quiescent region about the origin. The second type describes the situation where a gas fills a spherical or cylindrical cavity near the origin. The speed of the shock and the fluid-vacuum interface blows up at the instance of collapse at the origin and in both cases a global-in-time similarity solution can be constructed by inserting an outgoing shock after collapse. In either case the profiles for the fluid velocity, pressure, sound speed, and temperature at time of collapse are unbounded. In addition, we proved that the constructed similarity shock solution provides a genuine weak solution. These are special solutions, some aspects of which are borderline physical. Both types of similarity flows involve regions of vanishing pressure prior to collapse, raising the possibility that Euler flows may remain bounded in the absence of such regions. It was therefore natural to ask if there are mechanisms that could prevent such behavior. 

To test this effect, we first studied the multi-dimensional compressible Euler system for isothermal flow, then for isentropic flow, and finally the full system. We searched for types of solutions of physical interested that satisfy specific requirements and proved that the systems admit genuine weak global-in-time, radial similarity solutions with unbounded amplitudes due to wave focusing at the origin, even in the presence of an everywhere strictly positive pressure field. A common feature of our work is the use of a converging wave which is continuous prior to collapse. This is in contrast to Guderley's original solutions which involve a converging shock wave.

The PI has given research talks at five conferences, two workshops and two seminars, with the hopes that through these talks the field of hyperbolic PDEs was promoted and interest of students was engaged in order to maintain productivity in the field. Results and methodologies employed are expected to be a resource for future investigations.
